title: Cell Interactions and Fly Eye Development

content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The compound eyes of arthropods contain photoreceptor cells surrounded by other cells such as cone cells and pigment cells. Scientists studied how interactions between neighboring cells in the developing eyes of larval fruit flies affect the differentiation of <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells that normally become the photoreceptors of adult wild-type flies. One of their experiments is illustrated in Figure 1. <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="R 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cells are both present in a cluster of cells in the developing eye. <math alttext="R 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cells have cell-surface proteins called Boss. <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells have cell-surface receptor tyrosine kinases (<math alttext="R T Ks" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RTKs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) called <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></math> and contain the <math alttext="G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is involved in intracellular signaling. <math alttext="R T Ks" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RTKs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are proteins with an extracellular portion that binds to a ligand and an intracellular portion that transfers phosphate groups from <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to other proteins. Scientists examined the fate of <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells in fly larvae with wild-type (normal) forms of the Boss, <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins or in larvae with single mutations in the protein <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="Sev minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) or double mutations in both <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="Sev minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) and <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="Ras D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>). <math alttext="Ras D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> is a form of <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is always active. Figure 1. The fate of <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells in the presence of <math alttext="R 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cells when the <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R7</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells are wild-type (Wild Type) or have mutant <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins (Single Mutant) or have mutant <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins (Double Mutant) (a) Describe the first interaction that must occur between the <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cell and the <math alttext="R 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cell for the <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R7</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor to differentiate to an <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> photoreceptor cell.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The compound eyes of arthropods contain photoreceptor cells surrounded by other cells such as cone cells and pigment cells. Scientists studied how interactions between neighboring cells in the developing eyes of larval fruit flies affect the differentiation of <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells that normally become the photoreceptors of adult wild-type flies. One of their experiments is illustrated in Figure 1. <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="R 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cells are both present in a cluster of cells in the developing eye. <math alttext="R 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cells have cell-surface proteins called Boss. <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells have cell-surface receptor tyrosine kinases (<math alttext="R T Ks" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RTKs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) called <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></math> and contain the <math alttext="G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is involved in intracellular signaling. <math alttext="R T Ks" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RTKs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are proteins with an extracellular portion that binds to a ligand and an intracellular portion that transfers phosphate groups from <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to other proteins. Scientists examined the fate of <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells in fly larvae with wild-type (normal) forms of the Boss, <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins or in larvae with single mutations in the protein <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="Sev minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) or double mutations in both <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="Sev minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) and <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="Ras D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>). <math alttext="Ras D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> is a form of <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is always active. Figure 1. The fate of <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells in the presence of <math alttext="R 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cells when the <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R7</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells are wild-type (Wild Type) or have mutant <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins (Single Mutant) or have mutant <math alttext="Sev" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Ras" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins (Double Mutant) (a) Describe the first interaction that must occur between the <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cell and the <math alttext="R 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cell for the <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R7</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor to differentiate to an <math alttext="R 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> photoreceptor cell.

(b) Describe how the defect in the Single-Mutant (<math alttext="Sev minus" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) <math alttext="R 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R7</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cell causes the cell to become a cone cell instead of a photoreceptor cell.

(c) The scientists predict that the presence of activated <math alttext="Ras"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ras</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the Double-Mutant (<math alttext="Sev minus Ras D"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>S</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>R</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) <math alttext="R 7"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cell will enable the cell to differentiate into an <math alttext="R 7"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R7</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> photoreceptor cell. Based on Figure 1, evaluate the likely accuracy of their prediction.

(d) The <math alttext="Sev" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Sev</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="R T K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RTK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is expressed in more cell types than just <math alttext="R 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> precursor cells, and it appears to be important in determining the phenotypes of these other cells. Explain how one receptor can induce different phenotypes in different cell types.

skill.text: 4.B: Describe data from a table or graph, including: i. identifying specific data points ii. describing trends and patterns in the data iii. describing relationships between variables
